required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Self-learning vs Instructor-led Learning in BLS
clinical_study.official_title: Self-learning Versus Instructor-led Learning in Basic Life Support Training - A Randomized Controlled Trial

brief_summary.textblock: This study investigates whether there is a difference in the BLS skills in first year medical students directly after training and three months later, when randomly assigned to self-learning versus instructor-led training courses.

detailed_description.textblock:
This is a randomized controlled trial investigating whether self-learning versus instructor-led learning results in the same BLS skills in first year medical students directly after training and three months later.
When participants attend the "Erweiterte Erste Hilfe f√ºr Studierende der Humanmedizin" they will receive a short introduction about the study. The investigators will invite all first year students to participate in the study. As the study is voluntarily, participants need to sign a written informed consent. After that, the investigators will randomize the students to either group A or Group B. Group A will train their technical CPR-skills with supervision by a tutor (either general practitioner or medical student, all trained in CPR teaching) and group B will train without supervision. The participants in group B will not be allowed to communicate with each other during the training and they will be prevented from watching each other. The training will take about 30 minutes for each group. Directly after the training each group will be tested and the printed report form from the Laerdal Skill Reporter will be obtained for each participant. In the test the students will perform CPR in a simulated scenario as a first responder. The scenario is: "A male person has collapsed at the railway station." The participant should start CPR as learned in the training. During the CPR a departmental research fellow will observe the study participants and record BLS/AED actions on a scoring sheet.
The investigators will record three cycles of two minutes CPR (with five times 30:2 compression : ventilation intervals, as recommended by the current international resuscitation guidelines). During the three cycles an AED will be delivered and the study participant has to apply the AED and deliver a shock - after three cycles the study terminates.
After the BLS/AED competence testing, both groups will continue the rest of their first aid course together and the first part of the study ends. Three months later, the investigators will repeat the same scenario over the same time interval and record the same parameters. At the end of the second testing, a short feedback will be provided on the BLS/AED competence and further practice will be provided to the students to improve their CPR competence. From this point forward no further data will be collected.

primary_outcome.description: The percentage of correct compressions obtained from the printed report from the Laerdal Skill Reporter.

secondary_outcome.measure: Assessment of the participants BLS competences
secondary_outcome.description: Assessment of the participant's BLS competence by the study team. Rated on a Visual Analogue Scale from 0-100mm, where 0mm = completely incompetent, no idea what to do, and 100mm = totally competent, cannot be done better.

secondary_outcome.measure: Self-assessment of the participants BLS competences
secondary_outcome.description: The participants assessment of their own BLS competences. Rated on a Visual Analogue Scale from 0-100mm, where 0mm = completely incompetent, no idea what to do, and 100mm = totally competent, cannot be done better.
Degree of loss of competence after three months for all the primary and secondary parameters
The participants assessment of the teaching method. Rated on a Visual Analogue Scale from 0-100mm, where 0mm = completely inefficient, and 100mm = totally efficient, nothing can be done better."
Ventilation volume from the printed report from the Laerdal Skill Reporter (LSR)
Number of ventilations per minute from the printed report from the Laerdal Skill Reporter (LSR)
Overall ventilation volume from the printed report from the Laerdal Skill Reporter (LSR)
Number of ventilations from the printed report from the Laerdal Skill Reporter (LSR)
Number of correct ventilations from the printed report from the Laerdal Skill Reporter (LSR)
Percentage of correct ventilations from the printed report from the Laerdal Skill Reporter (LSR)

secondary_outcome.measure: Number of ventilations with too much volume
secondary_outcome.description: Number of ventilations with too much volume from the printed report from the Laerdal Skill Reporter (LSR)

secondary_outcome.measure: Number of ventilations with too little volume
secondary_outcome.description: Number of ventilations with too little volume from the printed report from the Laerdal Skill Reporter (LSR)

secondary_outcome.measure: Number of ventilations that were too fast
secondary_outcome.description: Number of ventilations that were too fast from the printed report from the Laerdal Skill Reporter (LSR)
the relationship between ventilations and compressions from the printed report from the Laerdal Skill Reporter (LSR)
Compression depth from the printed report from the Laerdal Skill Reporter (LSR)
Number of compressions per minute from the Laerdal Skill Reporter (LSR)
Compression frequency from the Laerdal Skill Reporter (LSR)
Total number of compressions from the Laerdal Skill Reporter (LSR)
Total number of correct compressions from the Laerdal Skill Reporter (LSR)

secondary_outcome.measure: Number of compressions that were too deep
secondary_outcome.description: number of compressions that were too deep from the Laerdal Skill Reporter (LSR)

secondary_outcome.measure: Number of compressions that were too shallow
secondary_outcome.description: Number of compressions that were too shallow from the Laerdal Skill Reporter (LSR)
Number of compressions with incorrect hand position from the Laerdal Skill Reporter (LSR)
Number of compressions with hand position too caudal from the Laerdal Skill Reporter (LSR)
Incorrect hand position from the Laerdal Skill Reporter (LSR)

secondary_outcome.measure: Time from start of test till call for help
secondary_outcome.description: Time measured from the beginning of the test until the participant calls for help.

secondary_outcome.measure: Time from start of test till first compression
secondary_outcome.description: Time measured from the beginning of the test until the participant makes the first compression.

secondary_outcome.measure: Time from start of test till first ventilation
secondary_outcome.description: Time measured from the beginning of the test until the participant makes the first ventilation.

secondary_outcome.measure: Time from start of test till first shock
secondary_outcome.description: Time measured from the beginning of the test until the participant gives the first shock.
If the pads for the AED are placed correctly on the manikin
If the participants follows the instructions from the AED.
If the participants checks for breathing
If the participants checks for responsiveness

arm_group.description: This group will train their technical CPR-skills with supervision by a tutor (either general practitioner or medical student, all trained in CPR teaching)
This group will Train alone without supervision and without communicating with the other participants.

intervention.description: Supervision by a tutor (either general practitioner or medical student, all trained in CPR teaching)

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- First year medical students at the University of Bern participating in the course "Erweiterte Erste Hilfe f√ºr Studierende der Humanmedizin" with written informed consent.
Exclusion Criteria:
- Students with professional BLS-experience, unable to perform BLS, or missing informed consent will be excluded.
